Class MancalaNode

  • java.lang.Object
    • GameNode
      • MancalaNode
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ScoreDiffMancalaNode

    public abstract class MancalaNode
extends GameNode
    MancalaNode - a Mancala game node. When using the constructor with fairStateIndex, a FairKalah (fair Mancala) initial game node is created where perfect play leads to a draw.

      • state

        protected int[] state
         
How to interpret the Mancala state variable:

Let the mancala pits be notated thus:

  _ _ _ _ _ _
_ 1 2 3 4 5 6
s             s
  6 5 4 3 2 1

where 
6-1 are the first player's (MAX's) pits,
s1 is the first player's (MAX's) scoring pit,
_ _
6-1 are the second player's (MIN's) pits, and 
_
s is the second player's (MIN's) scoring pit.

The numbers of pieces in each pit are stored in an array as follows:
state[0] ... state[6] store the number of pieces in 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, and s.
                                                     _  _  _  _  _  _      _
state[7] ... state[13] store the number of pieces in 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, and s.

Each player's goal is to end the game with more pieces in one's own
                                                             _
scoring pit.  Thus a simple measure of utility would be (s - s).

    • Constructor Detail

      • MancalaNode

        public MancalaNode()
        Create a standard Mancala (a.k.a. Kalah) initial state. This state is unfair: In play between two optimal players, the first player will win by 10 points. Irving, Geoffrey; Donkers, Jeroen; Uiterwijk, Jos. (2003). Solving Kalah. ICGA journal. 23. 10.3233/ICG-2000-23303.

      • MancalaNode

        public MancalaNode(int[] state)
        Initialize Mancala node with given state piece distribution with MAX to play. State should contain a total of NUM_PIECES pieces.
        Parameters:
        state - given state piece distribution.

      • MancalaNode

        public MancalaNode(int fairStateIndex)
        Create an initial FairKalah (fair Mancala) state where two perfect players will draw. Index -1 will return a standard (unfair) Mancala initial board state. Index 0 will return a random FairKalah initial board state. Indices 1-254 will return specific FairKalah initial board states. Indices beyond those bounds will throw an IllegalArgumentException.
        Parameters:
        fairStateIndex - either a valid state index 1-254 or an implicit request (0) for a random FairKalah initial state, or -1 indicating a standard (unfair) Mancala initial state.

      • MancalaNode

        public MancalaNode(MancalaNode node)
        Mancala copy constructor.
        Parameters:
        node - other node to copy

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        String representation of current game state. Example (initial state): 
             _  _  _  _  _  _
     1  2  3  4  5  6
-------------------------
|  | 4| 4| 4| 4| 4| 4|  |
| 0|-----------------| 0|
|  | 4| 4| 4| 4| 4| 4|  | <--
-------------------------
     6  5  4  3  2  1
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        String representation of current game state

      • utility

        public abstract double utility()
        Return an estimation of game node utility, unless game is over. If game is over, return actual utility. TODO: In your implementation, you must create your own subclass of MancalaNode (e.g. UserIDMancalaNode extends MancalaNode) and implement this utility method (inheriting all others). This can be confusing if you don't know Java well, so see the example provided with ScoreDiffMancalaNode. Example implementation: public double utility() { return state[MAX_SCORE_PIT] - state[MIN_SCORE_PIT]; }
        Specified by:
        utility in class GameNode
        Returns:
        double an estimation of game node utility, unless game is over. If game is over, return actual utility.
